posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: How come decades later most sword games still miss basic inputs like this?
posts.com:
Spin stick and time your attack to do a spin attack, tilt stick forward and attack to stab, tilt stick right and attack to swing right, tilt stick left to attack to swing left, hold attack to charge, etc. Especially the spin always feels so good and right to do

It's the first thing I test in games with swords and more often than not you can't do anything. Examples are Prince of Persia, Fable, Genji, Crystal Chronicles or even Souls games today

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Oddly, more obscure games feature similar inputs, like Maximo and Rising Zan. This is almost the Street Fighter meme all over again

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594662
It has to do with the speed of the combat and how mobile the character is.

In something like Bayo or Ninja Gaiden you're so much more faster and agile that it wouldn't feel well. Zelda games and Maximo are much slower in combat and you move a lot less. There are sometimes inputs that use the 360 but between 2 different attack buttons, fast enough frame data to make use of pauses (eg A,A vs A,wait,A), and the many ways you can dial up an attack there is no reason to resort to these inputs which as I said are going to feel bad with how fast and agile these newer characters are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594701
Eh, from my experience attack speeds of OoT Link are about the same in attack speeds of action games like Bayo. Note when i say speed i mean how many times you can attack within a second. Games like Bayo like to flub it a lot with stuff like spin attacks and similar such effects but you'll get the same rough 1-3 attacks a second. It is purely a visual illusion that Link is slower. That is just speed though if agility merely goes to options then yeah they are certainly more agile.

>>9593984
I had to shrink Temporal Tantrum MAP24 slightly to avoid breaking the coordinate distance limit. I think one of the Sunder maps also had to be shrunk during the testing process for the same reason.

Basically, if two points on your map are too far apart, it causes overflows in some calculations, causing hit detection errors like melee either missing up close or hitting from ages away, and archviles having infinite range.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Updated rules for A Serious Case of /vr/:
>Map must be made for Serious Sam The Second Encounter 1.07 version (this is the most up to date retail version you get from Steam/GOG)
>Usage of custom textures, sounds, and music is approved and encourged
>Usage of custom entities or other mods is NOT allowed. Outside of textures, sounds, and music your map should be 100% vanilla with 1.07
>Please provide a readme listing your name (even if it's anonymous), map name, and sources for any custom content used
>Map must be beatable (duh) and have proper co-op support
>Do not make edits of existing maps
>Project host has the final say and can deny your entry if it is not up to /vr/ """standards""" (please put some effort into your map)

Tips:
>Trigger a checkpoint whenever a new weapon is picked up to ensure everyone spawns with an "up-to-date" arsenal
>Make co-op portals for arenas that get closed off (and one-way doors for any closed off rooms/secrets so players don't get trapped)
>Aim to balance your map around Serious difficulty first, but don't be afraid to make support for other difficulties afterwards
>Also keep co-op in mind when balancing encounters, drawn out reinforcement spawners are not fun to wait on
>Hot Starts are not that common in Serious Sam, try making a "lobby" room for players to jump around in without risk of triggering anything (useful for co-op)
>A good fight is more enjoyable than a good looking room, don't stress yourself out over brushwork
>Use the official maps as references (I won't berate you for coping models, texture work, etc. from official maps) (You can have multiple maps opened at once and switch between them in the editor)
>Don't forget to make a thumbnail for your level
>Get creative with secrets!

Any other comments or suggestions? I will officially start this next weekend but anyone who's interested can start now if they want.

>>9574470
Mine was also a 32GB Memory Card. When started to having this problems I just formatted everything and tried to start all over but didn't work. So I swapped for the 4GB Memory Card I had and everything started working fine. Installed Enso on him and passed all the files from a fresh install to the SD2Vita that I bought and made a backup for this files because if anything goes wrong I have a safety. I also removed the Memory Card and didn't install anything so now I have two backups.
In your case you don't need to do all that >>9574464 if you already Enso your Vita using your Memory Card, you can just copy all the files from your Memory Card to the microSD(after you formatted correctly) and swap the ux0: on the YAMT settings and point to the SD2Vita. After that I recommend you to stop using and remove your Memory Card and just leave him as a backup if you didn't make a backup after you hacked your Vita.
Reminder to only do this if you Enso your Vita.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9574813
They designed games around using both screens. Nintendo pushed pretty hard for devs to make use out of the touch screen feature for the lower screen, and this led to quite a lot of square pegs jammed into round holes out of obligation, ergo needless and obnoxious gimmicks foisted on the player. Dawn Of Sorrow comes to mind, the stylus adds exceptionally little to the gameplay, and it actually flows a lot better if you use a romhack which removes the mandatory stylus poking.

Eventually this would be more relaxed, and thus for a lot of games, the second screen didn't serve much more of a purpose other than being something like a map screen, inventory screen, or status screen, which you could manipulate with your stylus if you for whatever reason wanted to take your hands off of the controls.
Those could be pretty convenient and handy in some games, but they also wouldn't have suffered if they only had one screen to work with. Some games were made with the touch screen in mind, such as some drawing games, or Trauma Center, where its application is actually pretty cool and thematically well placed, but most videogames aren't the kind where using a stylus on a screen is a critical or badly needed feature.

So, a gimmick which kind of could be cool for the right kind of games, but which was widely unnecessary. I want to liken it to if the Virtualboy could have been hooked up to a TV to play the games in regular 2D, and then only early games were made with the 3D in mind while most devs just put token efforts in for the 3D and expected you to play it on your TV.

To make this post more retro, the original DS had a slot for GBA slots, of course, so beyond the thing playing DS games, you could play all your favorite GBA games, or pick up later ones for cheaper as the market was moving away from it. Also, some DS games could have some form of interaction with prior GBA titles if two relevant ones were inserted, typically bonuses in a DS sequel to a GBA game.

>>9592197
Yeah it sucks, but here's how I cope on a modern diamond controller setup:
>left face button as A
>bottom face button as B
>right face button as C
>L1 as X
>top face button as Y
>R1 as Z
>L2 and R2 as the shoulder buttons

>>9592401
There's no physical back button by default, so you basically have 3 options:
>swipe up from the bottom of the touchscreen and tap the "Back" triangle on the bar that appears, or do equivalent "Back" gesture if you selected that option under system settings
>hold whatever button combo you set to activate mouse mode (for me it's L2+R2) down for 3 seconds, then press the B button. In mouse mode, the B button is mapped to "Back", and X is mapped to that thing that lets you view all open apps.
>try this https://retrogamecorps.com/2022/01/16/retroid-pocket-2-starter-guide/#Home
I have yet to find an emulator that doesn't let me map the "pull up menu" function or w/e to R3, so I just do that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9581145
>90s and early 2000s can't be grouped together. Radically different times for PC gaming.
>Things moved really rapidly back then.

This, you can't even group the entire 90s together. Shit got outdated stupidly fast. I am not joking, a top-of-the-line PC I got in mid-90s went from being able to run anything at the highest settings to no longer meeting the minimum requirements for anything in the span of a year.

As for what it was like, mid-90s had some wild games. On top of the AAAs which usually was a shitty port of a console game, there was shelves of smaller never heard of games that many times were experimental. The 90s was also the time of gross-out humor and Nickelodeon's peak so many devs were going all over the place in their game design. Even many of the "educational" games had fun aspects to them.

DOS based games could be a mess to get working, especially later ones that used mouse, sound, cds, or even 3D acceleration. They were a lot easier to use if they had a native Windows version.

It usually sucked to get a PC port of a console game, if it even was a real attempt at a port and not a horrible re-creation it was usually a poorer experience compared to the console, just listen to the music of the PC version of Megaman X. In Windows 95 a BSOD didn't even mean you had to reboot, many of them were recoverable since it would BSOD on the slightest thing, even trying to eject a CD while it had "pending locks" (e.g. the software saying "Wait! Don't let the user eject it!") would cause it.

The 00s was far more focus on 3D, but the early 00s was a mess of 3D hardware becoming standard in PCs and drivers being a mess with a system loaded with all sorts of expansion cards. A lot of the games were ports, and very hit-or-miss. Many other more original 3D PC games could be anywhere from great, to interesting yet repetitive or hard to control, to just plain boring with 3D utterly booming but many standards of how to design a 3D game not in place yet.

>>9581124
Generally speaking there was a clear distinction between consoles and PC gaming, with fairly different titles on each system.

It wasn't profitable at the time for Devs to make games designed for (usually) one or two consoles with already massively different architecture work well on the huge variety of different hardware and drivers available for PCs in the early 90s and 00s.

PCs tended to specialise more in FPSs, Strategy games (both turn based and real time), point and click adventures (which were not great fun on consoles until the Wii), longer form RPGs and Simulators of various sorts. Consoles tended to focus much more on racers, sports games, beat em ups, platformers (both 3D and 2D) and shorter form RPGs. What you get now, which is things being played fairly consistently across multiple platforms simply wasn't commonplace. Ports from consoles generally weren't that great, ports from PC to console were often even worse.

There were of course some games that worked reasonably well on PC and Console, some that come to mind were:
- the GTA series
- The Tomb Raider series
- Resident Evil 2 onwards

>You have rustled me with me this. So many frustrating memories trying to make different things work together on DOS, it was like a psyop to teach you about computers with no fun gaming at the end of the tunnel, sometimes.

I remember when I had created several different bootdisks for different DOS games that could only use the 640K of base memory in my 8MB Win95 system that all would load just enough devices and drivers and in specific parts of low/high memory so all the supported hardware would work while still having just barely enough base memory free to run the game. It's not like was that knowledgeable about computers at the time or could Google (Or even Yahoo or Metacrawl) how to properly setup such a disk, I learned almost all of it by accident over time to manage to stumble my way through creating that set.

Funny thing is, I got that game long after I had the floppy version of The Incredible Toon Machine and 100%ed it, even though Toon Machine was like, the 3rd game in the series and The Incredible Machine was the first.

posts.com:
>>9581750
>I remember trying to save up for a Pentium with a 486 processor and a few hundred MEGABYTES of RAM. It cost $1500 - $2000 (USD)

That makes no sense. Pentium and 486 were different classes of Intel processors, the Pentium being what replaced the 486. That would be like saying you wanted to save up for an "I7-12700K with a I7-13700K Processor"

Also a few hundred megs of RAM? That is an ABSURD amount for the original Pentium. I highly doubt there were any consumer boards that could support even 128MB for the Pentium 1 back then, much less several hundred. 8 Megs of RAM was considered mid/high end for the Pentium 1 originally, 16MB later. It wasn't until the Pentium 3 that 128MB was becoming a more standard amount to have, and that was still not a budget amount. There is no way if the 486 was still relevant that you were looking at several hundred megs of RAM. The largest harddrives at the time were 1-2GB, putting several hundred megs of RAM in a system from back then is like the equivalent of having 512GB-1TB of RAM in your home PC today.

>>9585534
>Not him, but says who? Modern oppion?

No, just the opinion of anyone who played it and had also played the SNES version, including me back then. I thought the game was glitched or corrupted or something when I heard the cacophony of "music".

Someone already posted a comparison video, how can you listen to that ear-rape and say it's a fine port? It's not just bad, it's not just a downgrade like the soundtrack of PC FF7 was, it's so horrific it might as well just be randomly generated notes. The sprites are all fucked too. Stretched and have a washed-out look to them, making them contrast far heavier with the background and giving them an appearance of not even belonging there when viewed on a CRT.

Is it as bad a Megman 1 for DOS? Obviously not, that wasn't even a port, that was an abomination to all that is gaming. But it's up there as one of the more infamously bad PC ports back then. A modern "bad" port isn't even close to what a bad port back then was like, now a port is considered bad if it has few configuration options, is locked at 30 FPS, and basically is exactly like the console version and didn't add configuration features for the PC version. But the truly bad PC ports were back from the 80s to mid 00s.

That's not to say there weren't good ports too, but when they were bad, they were REALLY bad. Destruction Derby for example was a pretty decent port to DOS:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-FDIp6fv2oo

Rollcage wasn't bad either:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_2Fv-3M-Ees

Come to think about it, both of those were racing games by Psygnosis. I recall liking many of Psygnosis's PC games back in the day.

>>9581124
Installers had access to the entire system and DLLs had no standard versioning system. Welcome to DLL Hell, where installing one program could literally break every other program with no way to diagnose it and often times the best solution just to reinstall the operating system, and then all your programs, and hope that you figure out an order that doesn't break anything.
Then you have 3d cards that only do one API properly (at best) so you don't even know what games are compatible, and that's on top of getting good drivers, which is a pain because your only hope is, at best, a 56k modem, and at worst a phone call asking your system builder to send you a driver disk, which they won't, because the tech support monkey is hell bent on being retarded.
But you put up with it, because at least it wasn't DOS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: One thing I remember is that shovelware games had a big if ephemeral impact on the gaming scene because they were marketed to casual PC users on shelves at Office Depot and CompUSA, and also often came in cheap bundles that would come in magazines or be found in bargain bins at supermarkets. Ports and shitty remakes of arcade games were perhaps the most common type of shovelware during this era, but just about every kind of game imaginable was represented. As a kid in the 90s-00s, you often got a mix of these games and more legit games from your parents, and since the wait to get new games(not to mention the hardware to run them) could be a long one, sometimes you just had to hold your nose and dive into your shovelware backlog after you got burned out on the better games.

>in the 90s videogames on the shelves were working finished products with no day 1 patch and having to wait 6m for the community to patch a broken product the developers will never fix

Actually, it happened more frequently that we would have liked. Just that with no internet, outrage did not went very far. Rather than Day one patches, you would get month One patches if you paid for the magazine with the CD containing it, if you did not have access to internet or a BBS.

- Jurassic Park Tresspasser.
- Point and Click Adventure games with scripting mistakes leading to an unwinnable situation. I remember I Have no Mouth and I must scream in particular, where if you murder a character before talking to him, an item you need to continue never appears.
- marathon 2: Durandal: Oxigen would not refill between levels, so you could stuck in a dead end starting a water level with not enough Oxigen. That's where I dropped the W95 version.
- Copy protection systems that did not work. It Got funnier in the early 2000's when if you had certain cd drives, the original game would identify itself as a pirate copy (Konami's Shadow of Destiny)
- Daikatana with broken AI beyond hope
- Uninstallers that simply deleted the entire folder, and at the same time allowed installing the game to C:\ (the root of the system)

>>9594753
I see this take being posted a lot more often in recent years, and I couldn't disagree more. I know it's a matter of taste, and if you don't enjoy something I do then that's fine really, but I can't help but feel that a lot of people don't give Sonic a fair enough shot and end up missing out on experiences they might've loved otherwise. When it comes to Sonic, the reason you run into things and get hit is because, well, you're going fast and, depending on how quick your reflexes are, you might not be able to react to things in time, it's something that varies from player to player and that's fine, but I can see why some would go through this and assume that it's all memorization...

Still, all video games require us to memorize sections we're having trouble with, and we're not supposed to be good at a video game as soon as we pick it up, it'd be shallow otherwise, if you could just run and win, then no one would've cared about Sonic, it's a franchise that rewards you for sticking around. One more thing that can help, is that Sonic's vulnerable when he's just running, but not when he's jumping... or rolling into a ball, always make sure to press down in slopes, not only do you gain speed, but you also protect yourself. Also, if you prefer something like Mario, then I can't recommend Sonic's 8bit library enough, they're a lot more Mario like than the original Genesis installments, Sonic 1 is excellent on both Game Gear and Master System, if you go for Sonic 2 then always pick the Master System version, otherwise it's too punishing, but if you go for Sonic Chaos then go for Game Gear, otherwise it's too simple. I hope you can give Sonic another fair shot, but if you prefer not to then that's your choice, but trust me, they're excellent video games.

>>9592623
In Japan they have what I call "trinket games", games that dispense cards or plastic trinkets that represent in-game characters or items, which you can scan into the game to use when you play them. These games get updated every 2 months or so with new challenges and new trinkets to collect, so players are not only constantly getting new content for the game, but need to play it constantly in order to get all the new trinkets they want before the next update comes out and replaces the old trinkets.

The first such game was Mushiking, where you collect cards of beetles and use them to battle other beetles, and I believe it can be fully emulated, with every update of the game having been ripped and every card's data having been decoded, making it fully playable in Mame.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bYL0-t4PoNo

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592623
>Makes me wonder how its still so big in japan
A few reasons. The first and most primary reason is probably just the fact that Japanese people don't usually invite others over to their house. Instead if you're going to hang out with your friends then it's more likely that you go out and do so. So for gamers, that means meeting at the arcade.

Also arcades in Japan did start to die out around the same time as the west, so what they did was shift their business model from games that will be ported to home consoles in 6 months to instead focus on games that you can't experience in your home. Or in the rare case of something that can be ported to home consoles, it can only be done as an inferior experience. Some examples of this would be something like the music game MaiMai which would be impossible to play outside of an arcade. Or Taiko no Tatsujin which can be released for home consoles but will always be inferior to the arcade version which uses a real drum. Arcades in Japan focus on 4 or 5 types of games that are all known money makers. There is also a big following of highly skilled players who are hooked on this games and will hang out at the arcade for hours every day after work. They cater to these players with constant updates and features like allowing your to record yourself and directly upload it to Nico Nico (I used to do this with MaiMai when I frequented arcades often). A lot of arcades also have one of a few floors dedicated to UFO catchers. The prizes inside are shit that people actually want and they introduce new prizes all the time. The machines don't cheat either, there is an actual strategy to winning so people feel motivated to actually play them unlike the shitty claw machines in America.

As for retro arcades, I can't speak for all of them but my favorite is a place called Mikado and while they do have a fantastic collection of games they also constantly have events going on and as a result of that they have a dedicated community.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592623
>Makes me wonder how its still so big in japan, I guess they just have more of a cultural following thats still active.

They have extremely great public transportation. Trains go almost everywhere. Most people who live in big Japanese cities don't usually have lots of room (usually live in very small apartments). So hosting gatherings among friends is best done by meeting outside at places like restaurants, karaoke, BBQ, arcade, etc. So a culture of "leaving homes to meet people" developed. It's why arcades lasted so long. It's far more comfortable to meet at an arcade with friends, then meeting up at someone cramped apartment.

Fun fact:
It's also why one of the reasons why the Microsoft Xbox 360 Kinect failed in Japan (besides them hating American consoles). You needed big living rooms to use it. Many Japanese didn't have the space.

Arcades were everywhere back in the day. Grocery stores, Landromats, 7-11 corner stores, convenience stores, Restaurant lobbies, Doctors office waiting rooms, etc. Not anymore. And of course the huge arcade businesses like Namco Wonderpark, Namco Cyberstarion, and Sega World.

-5% RAW Thrills generic shooter games.
-5% racer games.
-5% giant versions of mobile phone games like Angry Birds.

No actual Fighting game cabinets anymore.

No crazy experimental games from Namco or Sega anymore.

Remember Virtua On mecha?
Remember Craxy Taxi?
Remember Metal Slug on the Neo Geo?
Remember The giant Galaxian 3 cabinets?
Or the Ridge Racer Full Scale?
Or Sega R360?
Or Sega's giant full motion racing games?

I could go on and on.


The 1980s and 1990s were completely different. The ratio was more 50/50 an even split between ticket games and video games. Some Arcades didn't even bother with ticket games and went full arcade games.

I think Namco Arcades are doing well and survived 2020.

But Sega arcades were sold off to some random Japanese entertainment company called GiGo (?) in 2021. I guess Sega is still terrible at managing their money even after 20 years of promising to do better and almost goijg bankrupt.

>letting everyone have high powered consoles at home was a mistake

I sort of agree. But I have a an addition I want to add.

My personal theory is that arcades should have never let consoles develop online play before arcade cabinets had them.

What I mean is that Arcade cabinets should have been the first to have online multi-player before consoles. Online arcades should have been a thing years before Sega Dreamcast or Xbox Live. Imagine getting on a Sega Arcade racing game in the USA and challenging someone who lives in Japan or London.

They could have started country rivalries and people with the fastest race times to compete against one another across the world. You could have drawn people back to the arcades.

Or walking up to a Marvel VS Capcom 1 arcade cabinet, putting in a quarter, and selecting multi-player. Then the cabinet automatically pairs you against people from across the world. People would have been drawn back to arcades in droves to defend their records. Kids showing up after school to defend their records and their country.

If they could have done this in the mid 90s, I think arcades could have thrived again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592276
>>9592278
You don't need a FX2 chip. All the FX2 did was support larger ROMs than the FX1, the FX1 otherwise performs the same as the FX2. Many people assumed the FX1 runs slower from trying to use Star Fox 1 as the doner cart, but the chip used in Star Fox 1 was slower variant called the Mario Chip. The ROM of Star Fox 2 is small enough to be fully addressable with the FX1. The most likely reason that Star Fox 2 was going to use a FX2 chip is that they were probably not producing the FX1 anymore, not that it needed it. Even if the FX2 cost more to make, having production of both FX1 and FX2 going on at the same time when any FX1 game would run the same on a FX2 would have cost more.

There are far less games that had a FX2 in them, and even less that had battery SRAM. About your only option outside of Tealand is Doom and Yoshi's Island, both rare and expensive.

Meanwhile the Dirt Trax FX and Stunt Race FX games can be had for $10-15 at times and there were tons of those. Yeah, it does suck to have to cannabalize older SNES games to make one of these, but there is no real way to create your own from scratch due to it being an FX game. No homebrew way to create your own FX chip. I mean, it can probably be implemented with a FPGA but I have zero clue how powerful (and thus expensive) an FPGA one would need. I tried to lookup the hardware in the FXPak but all I could find was that a prototype from 2011 used a Spartan 3 FPGA, no idea if the current carts also use that. Depending on the version they go from $18 to $120, most seem to be $18-40.

As for making it, many have made such a repro in the past. Most of them back then were made with the beta ROM that was floating around for years before the SNES Classic. Issue is with this having been done years ago, most guides are listing parts that are no longer easy to get (mostly the EEPROM) but if you know what you are doing you can use just about any viable EEPROM that's big enough and has the necessary pins.

>>9587045
>>9587358
>No one asked for

I think you forget the sheer resurgence so many movies/TV shows had in pop culture thanks to DVDs and
Sure, VHS had been around long enough to be ubiquitous with home video, to the point there were still movies with only VHS home releases up until the last 15 years or so. Probably still a few. But by the late 90's, a lot of VHS were out of print, and nearly impossible to find in retail stores or even rental stores(Blockbuster's selection was always limited.) Forget about TV shows. Cassettes were expensive and took up a ton of space. But DVDs were dirt cheap to press, had a ton of storage, and took up no space. The sheer amount of media getting put out on DVD in 98-2006 or so was insane, getting full seasons of shows before that was a pipe dream, but now we were getting that. and your PS2/Xbox played them. DVD/game culture was very close at the time. I feel like the quintessential normie college dorm room in 2001-04 would have a Scarface poster and a PS2.

Plus by then the influence of a lot of movies on popular games was evident, and by gen 6 you could properly adapt movies as games in a less abstract way. GTA was clearly cribbing from Scarface and a bunch of mafia movies, so why not make a game for those?

>>9587369
There's semconflicting info in the manual and opening text. In her manual profile, it says that she's the "only survivor of her doomed home planet of Cerinia" and "roams the galaxy in search of answers." In the opening text, she "searches for the truth of her parents' death." Either way, she picks up a distress call in a small world in the Lylat system and investigates, the implication being that she has a feeling it's related to her troubles. You can infer that Cerinia was outside Lylat, she was orphaned recently, Andross had something to do with it and lured her, she dresses in a manner that's not unusual on her home planet, and that ship she used to board the Great Fox was probably how she initially arrived on the planet....
....and since absolutely none of that was followed through in the slightest, the Japanese version apparently cuts any and all mention of Cerinia or her parents, and doesn't even subtitle the line suggesting she might've recognized Andross, so she in the Japanese version has even less nuggets of back-story and is a totally random scantily clad blue adventurer.

>>9592436
The point of the phrase (overused and annoying and zoomer-y as it is) is that MOST licensed games—and even some triple A games—have forgettable soundtracks, but they're ABLE to get away with it because nobody really gives a fuck. No one's gonna play this game. No one's gonna buy it. No one's gonna enjoy it. So why put effort into the music?

By the same logic, it's a game developer's "fucking job" to make the game itself good. And yet we all know that licensed games generally suck. That means, on the off-chance that a licensed game turned out to be halfway decent, one could reasonably react to that by saying, "Damn, they didn't have to go so hard with this gameplay."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dual Analogs are cool but the design of the analog stick housing is really bad. The analog mechanism uses a thin, not keyed (basically around) metal post and there's no reinforcement at all around the slot inside the stick cap. What this means is that the stick can can rotate freely after the slot loosens even slightly which makes it feels weird to use, and inevitably the force of moving it will cause the slot to crack apart and make the analog stick go completely loose. Literally every single Dual Analog I've found in the wild has broken stick caps like that.

IT's really easy to fix thankfully. Disassemble, glue the slot back together, reinforce it with something, and put some glue in the hole to help keep it from rotating when you put it back on the post. I have two Dual Analog controllers and I had to fix both of them like this.

>>9591490
Other way around really. I'd be more inclined to believe that only early adopters of the PS1 even knew about the digital controller. Sony pushed the analog controller very hard after its introduction. System bundles always had the Analog controller after a point and they stopped selling individual digital controllers. The entire reason why the Dual Analog was missing rumble outside of Japan was because they wanted to get it to market faster and cheaper.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9593442
That's the Dual Analog controller, all the differences of note
>Longer handles (Longer than Dualshocks)
>Concave plastic sticks
>R2/L2 buttons have ridges on them in addition to being bigger than they are on the digital controller (same size as Dualshocks)
>No rumble motors outside of japan (if you have donors you can actually solder in appropriate motors into the burger/euro versions and they work fine)
>Analog button actually selects between 3 modes: Digital (Off), Analog (Red light, what you're familiar with), and a flight mode (Green Light, which basically just inverts the sticks to emulate flight sticks)
>The Analog mode can't be automatically set by games unlike Dualshocks you have to do it yourself.

It's a neat controller although the flight mode is ultimately kind of pointless when games could just invert it for you if they bother to have the option. It would actually be pretty convenient if you could use it to invert the analog sticks whenever you wanted but when it's in flight mode it ceases to be recognized as a Dualshock and does nothing unless the game supports the standard PS1 flight sticks such as >>9591962

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nintendo's marketing was incredibly confused and out of touch in this era. I think they never really grasped what they were doing wrong. the purple, sorry, Indigo main Gamecube color is an interesting statement that could've done well if not for the G4 Mac basically killing that era of colors in tech.
You had E3 2003 where they just come off as terminally uncool, passively aggressively saying other consoles are going too far and promising Nintendo won't publish that icky riff raff! Then their big reveal is being able to play multiplayer Pac Man with a game boy advance connector.
The sad thing is they WANTED a more mature audience as well and were friendly to it, but it ultimately never panned out. Gamecube starts off with Eternal Darkness and they made efforts to push games like RE4 or Geist, which they were hoping would bring in older audiences but they kept the family friendly games the face of their company
And then by 03/04 you have them seeing that these GTA games aren't just gonna go away and trying to push edge in their marketing , but instead of showing off stuff like Eternal darkness or Metroid Prime, its shit like Mario with a tattoo. Which is a funny image, but subtlety is lost on people so it just made them desperate to try and toughen up an image.
The GC for me is a tragic console. Even though it's highs aren't as legendary as Super Mario 64 or LoZ OoT/MM, it tried a lot to improve the mistakes of the N64

In Final Fantasy II, the Ultima spell has you going through a dungeon where a party member sacrifices his life for you to get it.
It's supposed to grow stronger the more powerful the rest of your spells are, but because of a bug, it deals very inadequate damage. When the programmer behind it was alerted to the bug by whoever was in charge, he argued that, being an ancient spell, Ultima should ultimately be inferior to more modern spells. Nobody else was able to fix the bug, and so it made it into the retail game, until remakes.

>>9590557
The date scenes are almost too subtle for their own good. The game is amazing at narrative subterfuge, setting up the audience for a love triangle only to hint that there's something more going on. The language implies lovey dovey but the underlying meaning is way more straight forward. Aeris tells Cloud that he doesn't have to pretend to be someone else and that she'd rather meet the real person. Again, like a big sister telling her kid brother to stop pretending to be something he's not. With Tifa's date she tries to say something and backs off. She says "Aeris would be able to say it" or something along those lines. You think that it's an attempt at a love confession but it's really Tifa trying to confront Cloud about his bullshit and Tifa is acknowledging that Aeris is way more assertive than she is. Both girls are trying to use the date to have an intervention and the love triangle gimmick is the smoke and mirrors to disguise it to the player.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think she's more important to Cloud based on his memories of his mother, where his flashbacks of her in Nibelheim are probably his most authentic. This makes the most sense because he never really knew or understood Zack's parents in Gongaga to really appropriate, and even when you do meet them, they act very different from Cloud's memories of his mother. Meanwhile, that Cloud in the flashbacks with his mother is probably the truest version of Cloud we see until the actual reveal come last disc.

She tells him to look for an older woman who can keep him in line, and Aeris does happen to be older, and while that isn't important, I do think the conversation hints more at why he's drawn to Aeris and the way she talks to him, even if that kiddish honesty of hers isn't exactly romantic and more arm's length, which is a luxury Tifa lacks and explains why she can never get to the point with him and can only say nothing at all for a long time.

I like the Cloud and Aeris pairing, but I don't think they were ever romantically drawn to one another. Cloud at most probably relates her to his mother, and that's why losing her feels hurts, but his inability to protect Tifa hits him so differently in comparison, he has to completely compartmentalize and repress the fact until he's no longer allowed to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Time Splitters (only on Game Cube)
>Time Splitters 2
>Quake 3 : Arena
>Half-Life : Decay (only on Playstation 2)
>Serious Sam : The First Encounter
>Serious Sam : The Second Encounter
>Metroid Prime (only on Gamecube )
>Medal Of Honor : Frontline
>Unreal Championship
>007 : Nightfire
These were the good games which looked modern and were on PS2, XBox, and Gamecube between 2000 to 2002. Certainly worthy competitors in the market (Metroid Prime maybe not aiming for the exact same market segments), but with the edge of splitscreen and online multiplayer, together with overall being a good game with good presentation, marketed strongly, I don't think there's any wonder why it did quite well for itself.

However, people forget that if you wanted a first person shooter on XBox, that Halo was the ONLY one there until 2002, where you would see a couple of middling games until roughly about a year after Halo's launch, where you'd finally see some good games on the console like Unreal Championship, Serious Sam, Timesplitters 2, etc. Thus, Halo had basically an unchallenged share of the market for a time, where its reputation did it well against middling or nonexistent competition on its home turf, letting it establish itself pretty well, with the PC port not coming until 2003, and which wasn't quite great, so if you were interested in Halo you probably wanted to get it on XBox. This would help set the stage for Halo 2 in 2004, which was a real barnburner, selling over two million units on its release day, and which had a popular and enduring multiplayer scene.

tl;dr it was a good game which in some aspects had limited competition, with a series which kept growing in popularity as it went.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You know what Halo was? The quintessential 7/10 that was released at the perfect time and on the perfect console. The only reason anybody continues to talk about this series like the second coming of the jeebus is because, for a brief window of time, it was the only semi decent game on a largely terrible platform -- and it was marketed by one of the biggest, most influential companies on earth. The game itself is painfully derivative; its sole contribution to the genre was making analog control scheme standard for console shooters. In every other way, Halo ranges from mediocre to outright bad. Let's talk about some of Halo's "innovations"...
>game begins with superhuman cyborg badass running away from every enemy he sees while human soldiers defend him, until he can find a general that gives him a weapon (and says he doesn't keep it loaded, even though he does. because uhhh... no reason at all.)
>first real level drops you into a wide open environment with absolutely 100% fuck all nothing to find, where you'll skirmish with a handful of small enemy groups and then drive a buggy and then it's over
>later levels are either most of the first few levels played in reverse, or the library, where you walk through endless blue corridors shooting the shittiest enemy ever designed for a video game for 2 hours
>every weapon is complete dogshit and outclassed in almost every way by the very first weapon you find. in fact, the only reason to ever use any other weapon is when you have no pistol ammo. at best, you might use the rocket launcher or sniper a few times in very circumstantial instances.
>no online multiplayer except on PC (which was botched), they seriously expected people to play 3-4 person splitscreen on giant empty as fuck maps unless they could convince a dozen fat retards to come to their house and play LAN (which 99% of players never did despite what anyone tells you)
This game, by the way, sold almost 1/2 as many units as Goldeneye.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9579129
Grenade buttons weren't invented by Halo, but that doesn't mean that Halo didn't have a part in popularizing them. There's many cases where an aspect may get credited to something even if it wasn't actually the first game to ever do it, often it's because the game in question did it both in a good way, and the game sold well, making a good and visible example.
You can look at FPS as a whole for this, Wolfenstein 3D gets touted as the original first person shooter, but it isn't true, aside from iD themselves having made the Catacomb 3D and Hovertank 3D games back when they were still the Gamer's Edge division at Softdisk magazine, there's simple first person shooting games on arcades and even computers and consoles which predate that.

What Wolfenstein 3D does though is put the player in a 3D space with textured walls, where they can move freely, and there's a focus on FAST gameplay, no fiddling with any stats or inventory, it's just shooting the gnutzis, avoiding getting shot as much as you can, while managing your resources and finding the exit to the next level (which may involve up to two different keys), finding treasures and secrets confers benefits of extra lives and putting yourself on your own personal scoreboard.
The gameplay is perhaps slightly too simple (hence being quickly overshadowed by Doom, which hits a fantastic balance), but more importantly it was a fast and widely available first person action game unlike any other.
Thus, it gets credit for assembling this into the very base formula that came to change the world.

Of course, nothing Halo does actually REVOLUTIONIZES anything, huge hits had done it all before, and it didn't reinvent grenade buttons, games like Team Fortress Classic already implemented those well, but it was one of those games which made the concept really take off because it was a fairly big commercial and critical hit which implemented the mechanic well and made it a prominent feature of its popular multiplayer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Halo was average at best. People thought it was amazing because they were young and impressionable when Microsoft's marketing machine kicked into overdrive to move units on the x-box, since it was the 'flagship' title.

I've played many hundreds of hours of those games in a social setting (split screen, LAN, XBL and Xlink). Why did I play so many hours on an average game? Because it was a good way to catch up with friends and let off some steam, since it geared as a party game, so people that weren't that skilled could still join and have fun.

In the group of course there were three fanboys that played even more than me, their explanations as to why it's "so awesome":

>it doesn't do everything well, but it puts together different things well
Perhaps the most honest answer, he can't point at anything in particular, he's played enough games to know Halo didn't invent much new, but likes that there isn't any major annoyances in integrating all the different systems (from controls to game balance).

>the AI
This is because the levels were heavily scripted, so for example someone might say "wow that elite took cover behind this corner there when it's shields were down, that was clever" - players don't know that Bungie just added these places into the terrain. Another level where you're on the beach, where grunts and jackals "fall back" because you shot the elite, there is actually a zone on the beach where they can retreat to baked into the game.

>the short time to kill, recharging shields/health
Honestly, I was never a huge fan of this concept but I think Halo 1 nailed it the best with the longer recharge time and and needing to venture to health packs. When they shortened the timer and fast regenerating health, for Halo 2 and beyond, it made the dynamic even worse (encourages people to just hide out of the action).

>>9579915
I don't care much for regenerating health, I find it's usually a crutch for not wanting to do better level design, but grenades being a quick button instead of its own defined weapon to manually switch to is just fucking practical and makes grenades more viable and fun. With a button I can just make a grenade throw and it automatically returns me to my weapon afterwards, that's smooth and I don't need to come to a halt, you can make the gameplay faster for it, and in return increase the challenge for the player to match their abilities.

In Half-Life, I find myself not using hand grenades all that often because that requires that I stop shooting what I'm using now and switching to another weapon, manually throwing it, and then switching back. Because of that, in the heat of combat I basically never ever use them because I don't want to let up the pressure, whereas I gladly use the grenade launcher altfire because it's very conveniently attached to my machinegun (and it also detonates on impact).
The role I end up using them for (aside from maybe demolition or setting off tripmines from around a corner), is if I have the drop on an enemy, in which case one or two grenades are my opening before lay down fire. This is useful, but more occasionally, and the grunts tend to avoid it, which in itself isn't bad, it's nice that different enemies require differing tactics and approaches, that's good, but it makes the already limited grenades still more limited.

If I instead chuck one with a dedicated press, I could maybe use it when in actual combat with the grunts, if nothing else to flush them out or suppress them.

You cannot underestimate how Bungie making the game easy to play played a huge role in popularizing FPS for consoles. All modern console FPS owe their thanks to Halo.

Bungie's Halo franchise had a significant impact on the video game industry for several reasons:

Revolutionary gameplay: Halo's gameplay was a revolutionary combination of fast-paced first-person shooter action and vehicular combat, with a strong emphasis on strategic thinking and teamwork. This new type of gameplay was a major departure from traditional shooters, and it quickly became popular among players and critics alike.

Story and world-building: Halo's story and world-building were also highly praised, with the game's rich lore and deep universe drawing players in and keeping them engaged. The game's story was complex and well-written, with a strong emphasis on the themes of humanity, sacrifice, and the struggle against an alien threat.

Multiplayer: Halo's multiplayer was also a major contributing factor to its success. The game's smooth, responsive multiplayer gameplay and robust matchmaking system made it easy for players to connect with others and play together online. The game's multiplayer mode was widely regarded as one of the best of its generation, and it helped to popularize online multiplayer gaming.

Xbox: Halo was a launch title for the Xbox and it was one of the main reasons why the console was successful. Halo helped to establish the Xbox as a major player in the console market, and it helped to expand the audience for console gaming.

Innovation: Halo was innovative in many aspects, such as the use of the shield system to regenerate health, the use of vehicles, and the AI of the enemies. These features were not present in most of the first-person shooters at the time and they helped to set Halo apart from its competitors.

Overall, Halo's combination of revolutionary gameplay, engaging story, and exciting multiplayer helped to establish it as a landmark title in the video game industry and solidified its place as one of the most iconic franchises in gaming history.

Bungie's Halo: Combat Evolved had a huge impact on the industry for several reasons:

- Gameplay: Halo's gameplay was praised for its smooth and responsive controls, as well as its diverse and challenging AI. This made it stand out among other first-person shooters of its time and set the standard for future console shooters.

- Storyline: Halo's storyline was praised for its depth, complexity and cinematic qualities. It was one of the first console games to have a fully-realized, cinematic story experience.

- Multi-player: Halo's multi-player component was also a major contributing factor to its success. The game's multi-player mode, which allowed players to compete against each other over a network, was a major breakthrough for console gaming, as it helped to establish the console as a viable platform for online gaming.

- Technical achievement: Halo was also a technical achievement for its time, featuring impressive graphics and a large, open-ended level design, which helped to create a sense of immersion and freedom for the player.

- The Halo franchise has also been a major contributor to the Xbox brand, Halo being one of the Xbox's most successful franchises and helping to establish the Xbox as a major player in the console market.

All in all, the combination of these factors made Halo a groundbreaking game that set new standards for the industry and helped to establish the Xbox as a major player in the console market.

First game was only Power and Wisdom. Ganon stole the power Triforce and Zelda hid the Wisdom Triforce by splitting it into 8 pieces. In order to beat Ganon, you must find the 8 pieces. Moral of the story, power can be obtained quickly, wisdom is superior, but must be obtained slowly. Or something like that.

Enter Zelda 2, they decide to add a third triforce, because the power and wisdom triforces are still recovered as per Zelda 1. The plot is that an ancestor of Zelda is in an eternal sleep. To wake her from her sleep means not giving up... so courage.

I thought the inclusion of "courage" kind of dilutes to significance of power vs wisdom from the first game, though it kind of makes sense. Without courage, power and wisdom are meaningless. But, on the other hand, courage was basically implied so no need to add it. They could have come up with a more interesting third triforce.

>>9591198
It's not about how "good" the qualities are. They represent three basic methods of achieving ultimate power, both physically and mentally.
You can be strong, but not wise.
You can be wise, but not strong.
You can be strong and wise, but lack bravery. etc etc etc
Courage is considered the most virtuous method because it's the method that involves taking direct action, no matter what your circumstances are. You may not be strong or wise, but with bravery (or even just "confidence," if you want something less dramatic-sounding), you can BECOME strong and wise.

But it is, as I explained and as you are demonstrating. It's unfounded grapevine because the fishing filtered idiots and haters saw potential for a big snowball

You are literally not and can skip them if they start to bother you, in contrast to many other games and the above-mentioned FFX (or Kingdom Hearts anyway), which has way more, way longer and way cringier cutscenes you can't skip, and no one complained, despite the huge Zelda/FF player overlap
>two goat herding games
That's barely two minutes and pure gameplay with great controls. >all of this stupid fucking pedantic
Riding a horse with great controls for a minute
>doing even more gay tutorial shit before you even get to the first dungeon.
You are exploring several different places, fighting (with a slingshot out of the gate) platforming and following the story. If you can't enjoy the presentation and gameplay, that's not strictly he game's fault or some imaginary tutorial's. Wind Waker wants you to do basic platforming with cutscenes instead of horse riding and hide from boars for an hour in a very generic fortress before you even get close to the first dungeon. Even the hyped-up Majora's Mask doesn't turn you into a wolf but a piece of wood and wants you to find fairies (very akin to TP's ill-reputed pearls) before repeating the same thing with toddlers and the game turning itself into a slow licensed-game platformer in an ugly swamp area
>and unfortunately it's emblematic of the next 60% of the game.
True, great gameplay and a lot of cool places to explore, hence the 96% rating

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9587326
I think it's an issue of standards changing. Nowadays, you'd get an E10+ or T rating from those elements. In the late '90s, however, people seemed to just care less about the degree of violence that appeared in children's media. So, you could get away with a little blood and death, especially if it was subtly put in.

The clearest example of "they could never get away with that today" in an E-rated game I can think of is Mega Man X4. One cutscene has a character slash some others in half as dark red blood splatters everywhere. Even with the whole "they're robots, so it's not really blood" defense, that scene seemingly got the X Collection a T rating alone.

>>9594213
That, but also Sega failing hard while still trying to push the "cool and radical games your parents HATE" angle.
Meanwhile Nintendo were slowly but surely understanding that making games that parents will buy by default for their kids is a goldmine. Hence the steady supply of half-assed Mario games on the DS. That way when some mom needs a present for little Timmy's 8th birthday it's "ah yes the Mario game on the Nintendo, it looks like a cartoon so it's gonna be fine". Then she sees a reassuring "E for fucking normies" rating and that's all she needs to know.
Though the real winners of the ratings wars were the DS shovelware publishers in the mid and late 2000s when they could put out any low-effort game that looked safe enough, got the right rating and would immediately look good to parents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Super Gameboy doesn't have Gameboy Color capabilities, Playing Gold or Silver on it will cause them to run in monochrome Gameboy mode.

If you want to play them on a CRT the best official option is through Stadium 2, Stadium 2 does a proper GBC emulation. You'll want a real copy however as flashcarts tend to be fussy with that game. It's also a good idea to put your transfer pack in a second controller while you play the game with another controller to avoid the risk of bumping it and making the game crash.

If not Stadium 2 than you'll want to set up GBI on a Gameboy Player.

posts.com:
It's kind of interesting. in the first max payne bullets weren't hitscan, for either you or your enemies, this meant that in slowmo while you could dodge projectiles so could your enemies at least by accident, you'd need to lead shots. imo though combined with the large bullet spread, sponginess of enemies and general jank of the movement in mp1, it made the shooting feel a bit blueballs, the premise of a graceful shootdodge into a combo of headshots never really materialized in the actual gameplay.

MP2 is much more conventional, you have hitscan(disguised by laggy effects but still hitscan), more accurate weapons, and enemies that universally get dropped by single headshots and a couple bodyshots in addition to refinements like a useful shootdodge and being able to fire on the ground. combined with the ridiculously broken sonic bullet time though it made most of the game a joke.
If they could have somehow combined 1's more fair bullettime and projectile speed with 2's refinements to the movement and bullet spread it could have been something special.

>>9590970
>It was promotional art made for Duke Nukem Forever. Hence why Duke Nukem is in Vegas. That art was from the Quake II build of Duke Nukem Forever.

it's funny how Duke Nukem Forever is retro and not retro at the same time. The development started in 1997-1998 with 3DRealms, and started with the Quake II engine. But then switched over to the Unreal 1 engine in 2000-2001. the game was delayed so many times, that 3Drealms went out of business in 2009 and GearBox picked up the rights and released the game in 2011. This artwork is pre Unreal build. It has the "Always bet on Duke" tagline from the 1998 E3 trailer, and also Dukes handgun is generic grey-metal. But in the 2001 build, the handgun was changed to a golden Desert Eagle. The Golden Desert Eagle also appeared in Manhattan Project. But for the final release, he has a golden handgun called the M1911 with a laser scope.
1998 Quake II build. Duke wields a grey handgun with an atomic symbol on it:
https://youtu.be/kR6qFFEkALg?t=150
2001 E3 trailer using the Unreal 1 engine. Duke is shown with a Golden Desert Eagle as his default handgun:
https://youtu.be/X6r3DWramKY?t=105
The final 2011 game with the M1911:
https://youtu.be/JYpqv0uDaSg?list=TLPQMjIwMTIwMjM48WPhqAIj9w&t=37

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592669
In each level, you drive around the area with your tank, finding dungeons to enter on foot.
Most of those dungeons are optional, but important so you can upgrade your gun. Although you can very well just find a good place to grind your gun, go back&forth, and then be on your way.
One of the dungeons in each level has a boss which gives you an upgrade for the tank (like a new weapon or hover or driving on walls etc), necessary to unlock the path to the next level, and so on.

You can strafe by holding the bomb button.
Try to always have your gun max'd out before a boss, I know it's not easy. Some higher gun levels are actually shittier than earlier ones too because of poor hit detection. If all else fails, find a good spot to spam grenade on a boss.

Other protips: some of the levels loop on themselves, or have shortcuts that teleport you to another area. It makes some levels more confusing than they should be (level 2 is actually the worse)
You only have 3 lives, 4 continues. Infinite continues in the JPN version. It's actually pretty hard to beat the game in 4 continues, you have to know where to go, I only did it after beating the JPN version.
At some point once you get a certain upgrade, you'll find there is nowhere to go with the tank. You have to think Metroid and backtrack to an earlier level.

Honestly play both (specifically OG Metafight for >>9590696 reasons). Blaster Master Zero gives you the outward impression of being a stright remake of the first game with its opening area and returning enemies, but then it throws a curveball and the series turns out to be a brilliantly subverted Metafight sequel.
...Oh, you wanted to dabble in the older sequels? Don't. The series was passed around Z-teams and didn't go anywhere until Zero, so you're better off ignoring them. The PlayStation game may be worth checking out if you want some context for a few story elements in Zero 2&3, and MAYBE try the GBC one if you just want more BM-otherwise, do yourself a favor and avoid the Western-made shovelware.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Considering Saturn was a failure outside of Japan, I'd say Dreamcast.

No one in the USA cared about the Saturn in the 1990s. It was a joke to a majority of people. If you went into a game store, it was either Nintendo 64 or Playstation 1 that dominated store shelves. Most stores didn't have a Sega Saturn display section. And if they did, it was tiny and shoved near the clearance section. Saturn was overpriced and just a terrible selection of games in the USA. No Sonic either. How stupid. No one cared about Saturn. And it just died and wasn't even remember by most kids.

Dreamcast at least had hype. I remember retailer's carrying the system and hyping it up. Selling special edition versions like the Black Dreamcast and other colors. It was a big deal. Too bad about Sega going bankrupt (because apparently Saturn drained their finances too much), but Dreamcast sold 3x the amount of the Saturn in half the amount of time. Much more memorable games too. Crazy Taxi, Soul Caliber, Sonic adventure, etc. If only Sega didn't run their business into the ground I'm sure Dreamcast would have done respectable for itself.

Your categories are very broad, but I can tell you that while Saturn has the Panzer Dragoon games, Dreamcast has Rez, which is a much cooler rail shooter with a neat synthwave aesthetic and dynamic soundtrack. Neither of them particularly have an abundance or rail shooters, but those are the big ones. There are plenty of arcade ports on both, and for RPG's I would honestly just go with SEGA CD or PS1 instead. Saturn does have Magic Knight Rayearth, but SEGA CD has Popful Mail and both Lunar games in English. Saturn has more 2D games but it's lacking in weird areas (no Sonic game, fewer platformers than Genesis and PS1 somehow, not all exclusives and arcade ports are quality games), Dreamcast has more 3D games and despite having a smaller library has more heavy hitters like Sonic, Crazy Taxi, and Jet Set Radio.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9589170
If you had to choose between the Saturn or the Dreamcast for playing games on the original hardware than the clear choice is the Saturn. The Dreamcast is a great system, but the majority of its best games have been ported or re-released on other platforms, whereas the majority of the Saturn's best games are exclusive to the console.

Saturn consoles are still fairly cheap as well, you can get a jap import model with a controller, a memory cart, and sometimes a game or three for around $100 shipped. Spend another $50 on a PseudoSaturn cartridge and you'll be able to play burned games. Alternately you can get an ODE fairly cheaply (from around $140 to around $220, depending on the model).

The Dreamcast can play burned games natively since the copy protection was cracked over 20 years ago, but since the DC supported GD-ROMs (essentially CDs that could store 1GB of data compared to the 700MB you could get out of a CD-ROM) a significant portion of the games on the system have to have data trimmed to make them fit on a CD-R. This usually means stuff like video being heavily downsampled, audio being downsampled, or sometimes audio/video being removed completely. The ODE situation on the Dreamcast is kinda fucked as well (they exist, but availability can be a pain in the dick if you don't want to buy the more expensive model).

Either console will have a solid selection of arcade ports, RPGs, and action games. Neither console had a ton of lightgun games - the Saturn basically has a couple of solid Virtua Cop games, a mediocre port of House of the Dead, and the typical Maximum Force/Area 51 combo (plus a few not stellar others), meanwhile the Dreamcast has a great port of House of the Dead 2 and Confidential Mission (plus a couple more gun sections in other games). Columbine happened in early '99 and basically tanked any US releases of lightgun games for a few years, so the DC got almost none.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560340
In fact a bad PSU will blow up the RAM before it harms any other components in the computer. The RAM chips have small, dense dies and are very easily damaged by overvoltage while the main chips like VIC-II et al have relatively large, coarse dies that can take a fair bit of abuse. So the RAM is basically like a crumple zone in a car frame; it will get toasted first and provide a warning of imminent PSU failure.

If you happen to find a C64 with bad RAM it's more often than not a PSU fault and an indication that you'd better throw that PSU away at once (occasionally you'll come across a machine with Micron RAM chips which do a fine job of self-destructing with no help needed).

in fact the very earliest 6502s from 1975-76 were 8 um. over time MOS managed to shrink this some. the VIC-II as anon said was 5 um but also had substantially more transistors than a 6502. by the time C64 was in development, they had two main production lines running. the first was the NMOS line that couldn't do anything smaller than 5 um. there was another line that did 3 um HMOS. the large process nodes that VIC-II and SID used were outdated by the time Reagan was president but they were there and there was no point in not using them as the production line was there and the VIC-II and SID wouldn't benefit from die shrink as much as a CPU or RAM. also MOS had years of experience with the older large node NMOS process and the initial production run of VIC-II/SID in 1982 got something like 80% yields. by the time they'd moved to the plastic-shelled R2 VIC-II in early '83 it would have been better than 95% yields.

during this time Commodore was trying to go down to 2 um for CPUs and other such components. they had trouble getting it to work which resulted in the notoriously unreliable PLA and TED. a lot of these were faulty; the PLA had such low yields that they intentionally shipped C64s with defective ones to meet shipping quotas with the idea that they would be returned and swapped out for known good chips.

yes those large node processes were outdated, but since Commodore only made chips for in-house use and didn't have to be concerned with consumer demand as Intel and Motorola did, they didn't necessarily need to be aggressive about adopting the latest tech.

HMOS is simply the name Intel came up with for the 3.5 um depletion mode process they developed for the 8086 and licensed to other manufacturers (initially tested on a DRAM chip prior to the 8086's introduction). posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The 8080 had a 6 micrometer die. Larger die sizes get hotter as more power is needed, and the power requirement goes up the more transistors are in there. So while a 6502 and its 3,527 transistors were not a big problem at 5 micrometers, the VIC-II had roughly 13,000 on the same die size.

Shrinking the die but using the same transistor count will reduce power use and heat output.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9587507
Heat is the main issue. A hot running IC will die early due to electron migration of the aluminum interconnects causing an open circuit. Most chips have a stated maximum temperature on their data sheet and the closer you get to the threshold the more likely it will experience an internal failure from electron migration.

It's usually one of those two things--overheating or overvoltage that kills an IC.

today they have temperature sensors to cut power off if it gets too hot, and modern high performance chips use copper metallization instead of aluminum for increased thermal capacity. most modern chips have a much higher maximum rated operating temperature than 70s-80s chips despite much smaller gate sizes.

The initial Famicoms from 1983 had a rather severe thermal problem and would lock up when running which led to them being recalled--those first PPUs had a sink underneath the chip with holes cut out for the chip legs to go through. The Revision B chips had a spreader on top of the PPU instead of under it, and it seems at least some units as late as Rev E were still sinked.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One of the most unlinear JRPG I've played must be Kaijuu Monogatari (Shell Monsters Story)

Here is some of what I wrote about the game

Surprisingly good DQ(2) clone from 88.
The game shines with its exploration and its characters system. There are 4 characters, each starts the game on a different side of the world map. You can start with anyone, switch to any character at any point.
The world is your playground with a LOT of unlinearility and exploration. You could probably replay the game 5 times and do things in a different order, or differently, every time.
The priority at first is to gather the 4 characters together, but once that's done you're free to split the team any way you like any time. This also becomes mandatory after a while due to treasure hunting at sea as the boat only carries two people.
The battle system is DQ2-like, but looks very dynamic: you can see your characters on the screen, and each enemy changes to a "wounded" variant when about to die.

While that unlinearility is the game's strength, it is also its weakness: it is hard to balance a game in which the player is allowed to go to many places in any order. At the very beginning difficulty is brutal, but after a while you're guaranteed to play 1 or 2 areas in which enemies won't be able to make a scratch anymore, although it is still possible to walk into a later area by chance and suddenly stumble on much stronger enemies (like in Final Fantasy 2), although area limitations are clearly marked for the most part. Also the entire late-end game spices thing up properly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594976
Level 3 is supposed to be your recovery/restocking level, and it's the last time you get easy chances at renewable pizza and recovering lost turtles. The building near spawn is for healing up who you have left. Then you punch through to the south, and cross the foot-bridge south-east of the building there. Enter the doorway on the right, rescue lost turtle. Exit, enter again for each turtle you need. Once you have a full crew, you can go grind scrolls in the building just west and north. Also has a full pizza in the basement if you need healing. Plus if you make sure Ralph and Mike are the two that go down, Leo and Don can survive just fine.
You'll be glad you have the scrolls when you start to deal with the really hard levels.

There is an elephant in the room: all output devices are supposed to produce more or less calibrated picture (and all the untagged picture data is supposed to come out as sRGB image in the end, even though that has not been the case for a long long time).

In simple terms, some monitors have much wider gamut, some other cheap ones have quite a limited one, and there is significant possibility that the illiterate user has some insane settings. The difference between those cases can be much bigger than the difference between correct and incorrect emulated colour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9593316
>>9593773
Lord, you don't even understand that I wasn't advocating their use, and simply nudged to look at their inception.

Let's get back to mid-90s, when ability to play a video or an animation in a window didn't mean you could automatically do the same in full screen.

https://archive.org/details/CDROMToday11Jan1995/page/n59/mode/2up

Stretching a single bitmap to a different size was not an instant operation, and doing it many times a second could easily exceed both CPU performance and memory bandwidth with all the pixel copying. (Even today a scroll through resized photos in a viewer can be noticeably slower than a scroll through the same files at original size.) Software had to rely on system-provided, driver-provided, or its own optimized scaler functions to be as fast as possible. It often wasn't even proper nearest neighbor scaling, but a block-of-pixel-based assembly routines hard-coded for the specific CPU memory bus width and cache size (or, later, MMX, or, later, SSE), possibly with some fixed dithering.

It is funny that with all the retro circlejerk it's hard to find the video of just a regular video player being used on real hardware. Unique texturing algorithm choices on the first generation of 3D accelerators can give you an idea of speed-optimized scaling results:

https://www.vintage3d.org/images/AT3D/gallery.php
https://www.vintage3d.org/gallery/permedia.php
etc.

Due to hardware limitations, it was still often not possible to do something the straightforward way. Games could use interlaced 120 line video clips to fill the 240 line image because CD-ROM and system performance couldn't handle bigger data streams. When Windows 3.1 media player was told to play the video in full screen, it simply grabbed the video card exclusively, changed the video mode to a smaller and faster one, and bypassed the Windows GUI altogether.

Fast scalers, rotozoomers, and the rest were also important demoscene effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595074
So-called 2D (GUI) accelerators and hardware overlay boards (often with a genlock for external TV signal) that could stretch your bitmaps for you had already existed as a niche professional market. However, it was finally understood that all that multimedia and interactive media often needed to use it on every frame. Video cards began to have dedicated hardware for that (and also began to consume YUV video frames, freeing the CPU from converting each one to RGB after decoding). See how review mentions that the card can stretch the buffer with bilinear filtering (!):

https://archive.org/details/pcworld151unse/page/227/mode/1up

Wow, we have that tiny worse-than-VCD clip playing in full screen with smooth pixels! Of course, bilinear filtering also gives you lots of blur, especially when dealing small bitmaps like NES output buffer.

The problem with hardware stretching is that it is done in hardware. The overlay variant specifically happens after the whole frame buffer is consumed and processed, and treats it like a green screen over which the given image is overlaid (duh). Software couldn't guess how good was the quality of scaling, as computer couldn't even technically get the result back from the screen. Still, it was important to offload as much as possible to the hardware to save CPU performance for the main tasks. Composite and S-Video outputs that later appeared often on regular video cards worked in the same black box manner. How exactly TV picture was generated from output buffer (the whole screen or active accelerated surface) was defined by chip makers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595076
In addition, a fixed set of desktop resolutions everyone used (640×480, 800×600, 1024×768) did not align well with console screen resolutions. Today you can integer scale that 256×244 to any ratio almost up to 10×. Back then, unless the emulator was a dedicated full screen application, you had to compromise by cutting part of the picture or making it smaller than the desktop (not so great when your monitor was already small). The other alternative was to zoom 2× or 3x, then slightly resize the output, and have either smudged or uneven pixels.

And of course, the aspect ratio of TV console output pixels is not 1:1, so to correct the almost-square picture to (more or less physically correct) 4:3, you had to stretch with different coefficients vertically and horizontally.

On the one hand, hardware scaling on a specific system with a specific hardware using specific resolution could be a blurry mess, a blocky mess, or a combination of both. On the other hand, emulators had to use it in most cases, and had to be prepared for that. The idea of all those 2× and 3x filters was to implement fast enhancing upscale (instead of the regular pixel doubled or pixel tripled copy) that would help contrast lines (e. g. text on screen) to survive the uncontrollable external stretching. They compensated for the less than stellar processing down the path.

Then after a couple of years, a couple of processor and video card families, and a couple of DirectX versions letting software interact with hardware through new APIs, it all slowly stopped being relevant. The rest is just wanking. First, some developers decided that all the increased computing power should better be spent on magical algorithms that could convert pixel art into high resolution graphics (they couldn't). Second, clueless users who discovered scaling options mistook them for some important improvements that could be used on their own.

If you have all the modern CPU and GPU performance to produce something that looks similar enough to the original thing, you never need the filters that were used in year 1999 to solve year 1999 problems.

https://www.nintendolife.com/news/2016/12/feature_the_making_of_metal_gear_solid_the_twin_snakes

Meanwhile in Japan, there was a team of individuals at Konami - handpicked and overseen by Hideo Kojima - responsible for the key creative output. "Most of the actual decisions were made in Japan, including any new ideas to add/update, reviews, and approvals." Toledo reveals. "We at Silicon Knights generally did the grunt work, while the team in Japan did the meat of the assets. We generally modified their assets to enhance visual quality and clean up and optimize code." Traver adds an analogy to describe how the partnership worked. "Konami had made it very clear earlier on that we at Silicon Knights were creating the VCR to play their movie."

This new imagining of the visuals also extended to the cutscenes. Where characters previously had static faces and eyes made of pixels, on GameCube they had full animation and lip synching for dialogue - all of which was re-recorded with most of the original cast. In the position of director was Japanese filmmaker Ryuhei Kitamura, known for his high octane action films. As Kitamura explains, it was Hideo Kojima's love of films that landed him the job. "Hideo came and watched my first feature Versus and loved it and we became very good friends. When I was making Azumi he asked me if I'd be interested in doing cutscenes for Twin Snakes. How could I resist?!"

The in-game cutscenes weren't merely graphical updates either. They added new action set pieces, showcased great feats of strength from characters and emphasised elements like bullet-time. Although fans have debated this creative direction through the years, it was very much the wish of Kojima to explore new territory. "Hideo told me to go completely new and different." Kitamura reveals. "He gave me total freedom because he knew that I was a big fan of his work so that I would never do something he wouldn't want. He also loved my second movie Alive
